title: Izaak Walton
text:
Izaak Walton (baptised 21 September 1593 – 15 December 1683) was an English writer. Best known as the author of "<a href="The%20Compleat%20Angler">The Compleat Angler</a>", he also wrote a number of short biographies including one of his friend <a href="John%20Donne">John Donne</a>. They have been collected under the title of "Walton's Lives".
Biography.
Walton was born at <a href="Stafford">Stafford</a> in 1593. The register of his <a href="baptism">baptism</a> on 21 September 1593 gives his father's name as "Jervis", or Gervase. His father, who was an <a href="inn">inn</a>keeper as well as a landlord of a <a href="tavern">tavern</a>, died before Izaak was three, being buried in February 1596/7 as "Jarvicus Walton". His mother then married another innkeeper by the name of Bourne, who later ran the Swan in Stafford. Izaak also had a brother named Ambrose, as indicated by an entry in the <a href="parish%20register">parish register</a> recording the burial in March 1595/6 of an "Ambrosius filius Jervis Walton".
His date of birth is traditionally given as 9 August 1593. However, this date is based on a misinterpretation of his will, which he began on 9 August 1683.
He is believed to have been educated in Stafford before moving to <a href="London">London</a> in his teens. He is often described as an <a href="ironmonger">ironmonger</a>, but he trained as a linen draper, a trade which came under the <a href="Ironmongers%27%20Company">Ironmongers' Company</a>. He had a small shop in the upper storey of <a href="Thomas%20Gresham">Thomas Gresham</a>'s <a href="Royal%20Exchange%20%28London%29">Royal Burse or Exchange</a> in <a href="Cornhill%2C%20London">Cornhill</a>. In 1614 he had a shop in <a href="Fleet%20Street">Fleet Street</a>, two doors west of <a href="Chancery%20Lane">Chancery Lane</a> in the <a href="parish">parish</a> of <a href="St%20Dunstan-in-the-West">St Dunstan's</a>. He became verger and churchwarden of the church, and a friend of the vicar, <a href="John%20Donne">John Donne</a>. He joined the Ironmongers' Company in November 1618.
Walton's first wife was Rachel Floud (married December 1626), a great-great-niece of <a href="Thomas%20Cranmer">Archbishop Cranmer</a>. She died in 1640. He soon remarried, to Anne Ken (m. 1641?-1662), who appears as the pastoral "Kenna" of "The Angler's Wish"; she was a stepsister of <a href="Thomas%20Ken">Thomas Ken</a>, afterwards <a href="bishop%20of%20Bath%20and%20Wells">bishop of Bath and Wells</a>.
After the <a href="Cavalier">Royalist</a> defeat at <a href="battle%20of%20Marston%20Moor">Marston Moor</a> in 1644, Walton retired from his trade. He went to live just north of his birthplace, at a spot between the towns of Stafford and <a href="Stone%2C%20Staffordshire">Stone</a>, where he had bought some land edged by a small river. His new land at <a href="Shallowford%2C%20Staffordshire">Shallowford</a> included a farm, and a parcel of land; however by 1650 he was living in <a href="Clerkenwell">Clerkenwell</a>, London.
Following the Restoration of the Monarchy it was revealed he had aided the Royalists, Izaak was a staunch Royalist supporter, and at great personal risk he managed to safeguard one of the Crown Jewels (referred to as the Little or Lesser George) following <a href="Charles%20II%20of%20England">Charles II</a>'s defeat at the <a href="battle%20of%20Worcester">battle of Worcester</a>. Walton was entrusted with returning it to London from where it was smuggled out of the country to Charles II who was then in exile.
The first edition of his book "The Compleat Angler" was published in 1653. His second wife died in 1662, and was buried in <a href="Worcester%20Cathedral">Worcester Cathedral</a>, where there is a monument to her memory. One of his daughters married Dr Hawkins, a <a href="prebendary">prebendary</a> of <a href="Winchester%20Cathedral">Winchester</a>.
The last forty years of his life were spent visiting eminent clergymen and others who enjoyed <a href="fishing">fishing</a>, compiling the biographies of people he liked, and collecting information for the "Compleat Angler". After 1662 he found a home at <a href="Farnham%20Castle">Farnham Castle</a> with <a href="George%20Morley">George Morley</a>, <a href="Bishop%20of%20Winchester">Bishop of Winchester</a>, to whom he dedicated his "Life of George Herbert" and his biography of <a href="Richard%20Hooker%20%28theologian%29">Richard Hooker</a>. He sometimes visited <a href="Charles%20Cotton">Charles Cotton</a> in his fishing house on the <a href="River%20Dove%2C%20Derbyshire">Dove</a>.
Walton died, aged 90, in his daughter's house at Winchester on 15 December 1683 and was buried in <a href="Winchester%20Cathedral">Winchester Cathedral</a>.
Walton's cottage at Shallowford.
Walton left his property as described above at <a href="Shallowford%2C%20Staffordshire">Shallowford</a> in <a href="Staffordshire">Staffordshire</a> for the benefit of the poor of his native town. He had purchased Halfhead Farm there in May 1655. In doing this he was part of a more general retreat of Royalist gentlemen into the English countryside, in the aftermath of the <a href="English%20Civil%20War">English Civil War</a>, a move summed up by his friend Charles Cotton's well-known poem "The Retirement" (first published in the 5th edition of Walton's "Compleat Angler"). The cost of Shallowford was £350, and the property included a farmhouse, a cottage, courtyard, garden and nine fields along which a river ran. Part of its attraction may have been that the River Meece, which he mentions in one of his poems, formed part of the boundary. The farm was let to tenants, and Walton kept the excellent fishing.
The cottage is now a Walton Museum. The ground floor of the museum is set-out in period, with information boards covering Walton's life, his writings and the story of the Izaak Walton Cottage. Upstairs a collection of fishing related items is displayed, the earliest dating from the mid-eighteenth century, while a room is dedicated to his "Lives" and "The Compleat Angler". The Izaak Walton Cottage and gardens are open to the public on Sunday afternoons during the summer.
"The Compleat Angler".
"The Compleat Angler" was first published in 1653, but Walton continued to add to it for a quarter of a century. It is a celebration of the art and spirit of fishing in prose and verse; 6 verses were quoted from <a href="John%20Dennys">John Dennys</a>'s 1613 work "<a href="The%20Secrets%20of%20Angling">The Secrets of Angling</a>". It was dedicated to John Offley, his most honoured friend. There was a second edition in 1655, a third in 1661 (identical with that of 1664), a fourth in 1668 and a fifth in 1676. In this last edition the thirteen chapters of the original had grown to twenty-one, and a second part was added by his friend and brother angler <a href="Charles%20Cotton">Charles Cotton</a>, who took up Venator where Walton had left him and completed his instruction in <a href="fly%20fishing">fly fishing</a> and the making of <a href="Artificial%20fly">flies</a>.
Walton did not profess to be an expert with a fishing fly; the fly fishing in his first edition was contributed by <a href="Thomas%20Barker%20%28fishing%20guide%29">Thomas Barker</a>, a retired cook and <a href="humorist">humorist</a>, who published a <a href="treatise">treatise</a> of his own, "The Art of Angling" in 1651; but in the use of the live <a href="worm">worm</a>, the <a href="grasshopper">grasshopper</a> and the <a href="frog">frog</a> "Piscator" himself could speak as a master. The famous passage about the frog, often misquoted as being about the worm—"use him as though you loved him, that is, harm him as little as you may possibly, that he may live the longer"—appears in the original edition. The additions made as the work grew did not affect the technical part alone; quotations, new turns of phrase, songs, poems and anecdotes were introduced as if the author, who wrote it as a recreation, had kept it constantly in his mind and talked it over point by point with his many friends. There were originally only two interlocutors in the opening scene, "Piscator" and "Viator"; but in the second edition, as if in answer to an objection that "Piscator" had it too much in his own way in praise of angling, he introduced the <a href="falconry">falconer</a>, "Auceps," changed "Viator" into "Venator" and made the new companions each dilate on the joys of his favourite sport.
The best-known old edition of the "Angler" is J. Major's (2nd ed., 1824). The book was edited by <a href="Andrew%20Lang">Andrew Lang</a> in 1896, followed by many other editions.
Walton's "Lives".
Walton also made significant contributions to seventeenth-century life-writing throughout his career. His leisurely labours as a biographer seem to have grown out of his devotion to angling. It was probably as an angler that he made the acquaintance of Sir <a href="Henry%20Wotton">Henry Wotton</a>, but it is clear that Walton had more than a love of fishing and a humorous temper to recommend him to the friendship of the accomplished ambassador. At any rate, Wotton, who had intended to write the life of <a href="John%20Donne">John Donne</a>, and had already corresponded with Walton on the subject, left the task to him. Walton had already contributed an <a href="elegy">elegy</a> to the 1633 edition of Donne's poems, and he completed and published the life, much to the satisfaction of the most learned critics, in 1640. Sir Henry Wotton dying in 1639, Walton undertook his life also; it was finished in 1642 and published in 1651 as a preface to the volume "Reliquiae Wottonianae". His life of <a href="Richard%20Hooker">Hooker</a> was published in 1665, and his biography of <a href="George%20Herbert">George Herbert</a> in 1670, the latter coinciding with a collected edition of Walton's biographical writings, "The Lives of Dr. John Donne, Sir Henry Wotton, Mr. Richard Hooker, Mr. George Herbert" (1670, 1675). His life of Bishop <a href="Robert%20Sanderson%20%28theologian%29">Robert Sanderson</a> appeared in 1678. All these subjects were endeared to the biographer by a certain gentleness of disposition and cheerful piety; three of them at least—Donne, Wotton and Herbert—were anglers. Walton studied these men's lives in detail, and provides many insights into their character.
Walton in literature.
Walton has appeared in a number of works of literature, both non-fiction and fiction.
Fiction.
<a href="Charles%20Dickens">Charles Dickens</a> makes reference to him in chapter 14 of book 2 of <a href="A%20Tale%20of%20Two%20Cities">A Tale of Two Cities</a>. "The honoured parent steering Northward, had not gone far, when he was joined by another disciple of Izaak Walton, and the two trudged on together."
Other commemorations.
Advertising mogul and land developer <a href="Barron%20Collier">Barron Collier</a> founded the Izaak Walton Fly Fishing Club in 1908 at his <a href="Useppa%20Island">Useppa Island</a> resort near <a href="Fort%20Myers%2C%20Florida">Fort Myers, Florida</a>. The <a href="Izaak%20Walton%20League">Izaak Walton League</a> is an American association formed in 1922 in <a href="Chicago%2C%20Illinois">Chicago, Illinois</a>, to preserve fishing streams. Walton has been inducted into the American <a href="National%20Fresh%20Water%20Fishing%20Hall%20of%20Fame">National Fresh Water Fishing Hall of Fame</a>. There is a forest preserve in Homewood, Illinois, called the Izaak Walton Forest Preserve. The Izaak Walton Hotel, in the Staffordshire village of Ilam overlooks the river Dove, at the entrance to Dovedale. There are also two pubs in England named The Izaak Walton: one in the village of <a href="East%20Meon">East Meon</a>, Hampshire, the other in <a href="Cresswell%2C%20Staffordshire">Cresswell</a>, <a href="Staffordshire">Staffordshire</a>. In the county town of <a href="Stafford">Stafford</a>, there is now a statue of him placed in the town park, by the bank of the river. This route through the park was originally known as 'Izaak Walton Walk', there is also a street in the north part of Stafford named for him.
There is a creek named after him in <a href="Owatonna%2C%20Minnesota">Owatonna, Minnesota</a>. There is also a pub in <a href="Norwich">Norwich</a> named 'The Compleat Angler'. The Compleat Angler Hotel in <a href="Bimini">Bimini</a>, <a href="Bahamas">Bahamas</a>, was destroyed by fire in 2006; the hotel bar was frequented by <a href="Ernest%20Hemingway">Ernest Hemingway</a>. The Allen-Edmonds shoe company of <a href="Port%20Washington%2C%20Wisconsin">Port Washington, Wisconsin</a>, produces a "Walton" style in tribute. In the Silver Divide region of the <a href="Sierra%20Nevada%20%28U.S.%29">Sierra Nevada</a> mountain range of California, a major peak is named after Izaak Walton. The Izaak Walton State Recreation Site in <a href="Sterling%2C%20Alaska">Sterling, Alaska</a>, is located at the confluence of the Moose River and the <a href="Kenai%20River">Kenai River</a>, and his name is lent to the historic <a href="Izaak%20Walton%20Inn">Izaak Walton Inn</a> in Montana. There is an Izaak Walton Inn in Embu, Kenya, overlooking a small stream that feeds into the Rupingazi River.
In the movie "<a href="School%20Ties">School Ties</a>" (1992) the history teacher refers to Izaak Walton as a personal favorite after mentioning the date of his birth to see if any students knew it.
